title: Autumn statement 2014 - as it happened | UK news | The Guardian
summary: small print alert : uk productivity lags behind .
small print alert : treasury document does not show nhs getting an extra £ 2bn a year .
small print alert : obr accuses dwp of `` optimism bias '' over universal credit .

documents.title: summary : the political impact
text: if george osborne thought that his stamp duty reforms were going pose a trap for labour , and that ed miliband was going to vote against them , then he 's wasted £ 800m ( details here ) .
but , actually , politics is never that simplistic , and osborne was almost certainly more influenced by the thought that voters would welcome this as a good idea .
he 's almost certainly right , and the overall immediate reaction to the autumn statement will probably be positive .
in fact , as a case study in how to conjure up good news from an empty cupboard , the autumn statement 2014 will be hard to beat .
it seems like we have had a rolling four-day festival of positive spending announcements ( although seems '' is the operative word - many were recycled , or quite what they appeared . )
and , to be fair , there were some very welcome measures in the statement too , for example on corporate tax avoidance and post-graduate loans .
overall , though , the big political is much the same as it was this morning , and what is really interesting is what the obr has been saying about future spending cuts .
presumably the ifs will make the same point in its briefing tomorrow .
the future outlook for the public finances is precarious , and whoever becomes chancellor after the next election is going to have to make some wretched choices .
on that cheery note , goodnight .
and thanks for the comments .
george osborne leaving the houses of parliament after delivering the autumn statement .
tallis/afp/getty images
the chancellor poses as steadfast , but he continually rewrites his 'long-term plan ' and has not come clean about the dreadful consequences of the endless cutting buried in the smallprint '' .
that 's a summary of our take on the autumn statement : the guardian view on george osborne : he can not be serious
so much for autumn statements being a mere update on the economy , as george osborne promised in 2010 .
chris sanger , ey 's head of tax policy , has crunched the numbers and reckons today 's statement has more policy changes than march 's budget .
today 's autumn statement was a reversion to form and even more like a budget than the one in march , with 59 policy measures compared to 56 earlier this year .
with the election around the corner , the chancellor was clearly more focused on the politics of the day than worries over tinkering with the tax system . ''
more anecdotal evidence of the impact of the stamp duty changes : joel hills ( @ itvjoel ) just spoken to estate agent who recently agreed sale on house in belgravia for £ 16m .
he is about to tell buyer his stamp duty bill up 500k !
jess brammar ( @ jessbrammar ) friend buying a flat that 's £ 250k ( ie just under stamp duty slab threshold ) .
offer accepted , seller just pulled out and gave no reason .
hmmm jess brammar ( @ jessbrammar ) wonder if flat will go back on the market straight away at a slightly higher price
we like to cover every angle on these big occasions , so here 's the fashion world 's take on the chancellor 's new , spruced-up image .
here , fairly randomly , are two striking tweets from journalists about the autumn statement .
john mcdermott ( @ johnpmcdermott ) the autumn statement can distract us from the big here it is .
chris cook ( @ xtophercook ) i find myself staring at this chart quite a lot .
# autumnstatement
this is a good spot , from my colleague greg wood .

the horserace betting levy , a statutory system which has returned money to the horse racing industry from off-course betting shops for nearly 50 years , could be replaced by a legally-enforceable right to accept bets on the sport .
the government announced in the autumn statement that it will consult in early 2015 on the introduction of a horserace betting authorisation .

under the proposed scheme , bookmakers will be allowed to accept bets on horse racing only if they have acquired the right to do so by agreeing to pay a fixed proportion of their profits to the sport .
the plan , which has attracted broad cross-party support , is expected to be subject to a four-week consultation process .
it would replace a system which currently delivers about £ 85m to racing annually to fund prize-money , veterinary research and improvements to facilities .
here 's a nice stamp duty factoid .
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) stamp duty was first introduced in 1694 to pay for war with france

documents.title: small print alert : uk productivity lags behind
text: george osborne was keen today to contrast britain 's strong growth this year with the lacklustre performances of germany and france .
but take a look at productivity growth , and its clear that the eurozone 's two biggest members have outshone the uk .
indeed , only italy - which has n't grown for the last 12 quarters - has done worse : productivity of g7 countries .
the government has announced some pro-productivity measures today , such as tax breaks for taking on an apprentice and strengthened tax credits for research and development .
the £ 15bn roads programme is also designed to help .

but terry scuoler , chief executive of eef , the manufacturers ' organisation , argues that more could be done : ultimately manufacturers would have liked to have seen greater levels of funding and longer- term commitments to spending on innovation . ''
back / barcroft media/ .
the autumn statement has acted like a crowbar in the fractures that run through the coalition .

vince cable , business secretary , has demanded that the office for budget responsibility spell out the difference between tory and liberal democrat economic plans amid concerns that the treasury has not been honest enough about the impact of future spending cuts .

political editor patrick wintour has the scoop : the extraordinary intervention - emerging in the aftermath of the autumn statement given by george osborne - represents an attempt by the business secretary to assert the independence of liberal democrat economic policymaking after more than four years of coalition government .
cable - who remains a member of the cabinet - wrote to the obr in the past two weeks ; his letter as well as a reply from the obr is due to be published shortly .

it is understood cable asked the government 's fiscal watchdog to make sure it spelled out what was agreed coalition economic policy and what was going to be implied by the obr in its forecasts about future spending and cuts after the election .

full story : vince cable delivers broadside against autumn statement figures and here 's some instant reaction : dan hodges ( @ dpjhodges ) if vince cable does n't agree with what the government 's doing , fine .
he should leave it .
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) extraordinarily the business sectretary @ twitterid has written to obr asking for a special libdem forecast on impact of further cuts

documents.title: small print alert : treasury document does not show nhs getting an extra £ 2bn a year
text: ed balls , the shadow chancellor , has been briefing journalists at westminster on the autumn statement .
here are some of the key points he 's been making .
balls confirmed that labour was backing the stamp duty reform and that , if anything , this strengthened the case for a mansion tax .
once you concede that the top end of the housing market is under-taxed , it is not clear why you would only choose a tax on transactions that only applies on transfers .
he said that the treasury 's autumn statement green book did not support osborne 's claim that the nhs is getting an extra £ 2bn a year .
on sunday the treasury claimed this was a permanent , year-on-year increase , although it conceded that £ 750m was coming from the department for health 's budget .
the rest was coming from underspends in other departments , it said .
but balls pointed out that page 65 of the green book shows that this extra money is only factored in for one year .
in the accounts for future years it does not feature .
balls said that he had asked danny alexander about this in a tv interview and that alexander could not give an explanation .
balls said : it 's not there .
it does not exist .
it 's a con it is very hard to spend a prospective underspend .
how can you know the department is going to underspend in the future ?
he said that george osborne is borrowing £ 219bn more over this parliament than he planned in november 2010 .
balls said that roughly halving the deficit over this parliament was what alistair darling proposed in 2010 , in a plan osborne criticised .
now osborne is claiming this is a good outcome , he said .
balls said real wages were forecast to fall by 4 % over this parliament .
he said average earnings had been revised down this year , next year and in 2016 .
as
ian stewart , chief economist at deloitte , hammers home the point that britain is only halfway through its austerity programme .
despite disappointing growth in revenues today 's deficit forecasts were n't quite as bad as some feared .
but that should n't obscure the fact that we are only half way through a deficit reduction programme which stretches towards the end of the next parliament .
the imf reckons that the uk deficit this year will be larger those in greece , france , italy or ireland .
the obr is forecasting a tightening of fiscal policy and cuts in real government consumption spending for each of the next five years .
the private sector will have to compensate for this and drive uk growth through the next parliament . ''
ed conway ( @ edconwaysky ) obr : govt 's fiscal plans imply 3 successive yrs of cash reductions in govt consumption of goods/services from 2016 onwards , first since 1948
video : here 's david cameron 's bungled attempt to accuse ed balls of political sado-masochism at pmqs today : a predictable joke about the chief whip is left as an exercise for the reader .

documents.title: small print alert : obr accuses dwp of `` optimism bias '' over universal credit
text: we 've already mentioned the obr 's comment about the government saving money from the universal credit delays ( see 3.37pm ) , but this is worth a mention because it is a wonderful addition to the lexicon of whitehall euphemism .
the obr accuses the dwp of optimism bias '' .
that 's a polite way of saying wishful thinking '' .
here 's the quote .

as we have considered the evidence on the centrality of these plans - including the cross- government scrutiny that has taken place - and have weighed that against the recent history of optimism bias in universal credit plans and other projects of this sort .
george osborne has also given a helping hand to buy-to-let landlords with his stamp duty plans .

that 's according to stephen ludlow , chairman of estate agent ludlowthompson , who explains : buy-to-let landlords usually invest in properties below £ 937,500 , so the changes will give almost all investors in this market a boost . ''

the changes in stamp duty will see the biggest increase in net returns for more modestly investments - smaller properties in zone 3 of london , city centre apartments , flats above shops , ex-local authority property and property in secondary locations . ''
just the kind of properties that struggling first-time buyers might hope to acquire
george osborne actually paid tribute to gordon brown as he took questions in the commons on his statement , according to the press association .
osborne was replying to a question from kenneth clarke , who said ed balls was not as committed to financial discipline as brown was when he was in opposition .

osborne replied : you of course make a good observation about the shadow chancellor 's career and i think it is probably the first time i 've ever done this but i should pay tribute to mr brown who has announced his retirement this week , firstly for his commitment to something i totally support which [ is the ] advance of international development and the commitment to british aid .
the second - when he was shadow chancellor he built up a really compelling case for fiscal discipline and that 's why the labour party won the 1997 general election in part .
it is in such a marked contrast to the shambles we see from the pair opposite who subsequently advised him .
slightly alarmingly , the obr ends its briefing by admitting that it 's not certain that uk productivity will recover ; economist stephen nickell says it 's an 'act of faith ' .
katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) obr briefing ends with assertion that the hope productivity growth will return and boost wage growth is an `` act of faith '' from obr 's nickell
the lib dems have pointed out that george osborne 's stamp duty reforms are in line with longstanding lib dem policy .
as you will all remember , policy paper 81 , passed at the lib dem conference in 2007 , said the regressive slab '' structure of stamp duty should be reformed .
as
this chart for the obr 's economic and fiscal outlook shows how the stamp duty changes will cost around £ 800m per annum : .
guy harding ( @ guyhardingsky ) @ katieallengdn @ twitterid £ 395m hit to the government coffers for the next four months alone .
ouch !

documents.title: small print alert : government policies benefit relatively well-off the most
text: in his speech george osborne said the richest 20 % were contributing more to the government 's deficit reduction programme than everyone else put together .
the net contribution of the richest 20 % will be larger than the remaining 80 % put together - proving we are all in this together .
now , at every budget and autumn statement , the treasury produces a distributional income analysis , showing which income groups gain and lose from the government 's decisions .
today 's one is here ( pdf ) .
the 20 % claim is based on chart 2.h on page 19 , showing the impact of all tax , welfare and public spending decisions taken since june 2010 on income quintiles .
but , if the richest 20 % have lost the most , the group that has lost the next most are the poorest 20 % .
and households in the fourth quintile - the richest 60 to 80 % - have done best .
they are the only quartile to have actually gained since 2010 .
so , it is not the middle that is being squeezed ; it 's the richest and the poorest .
on page 29 of the document there is a chart showing which decile your household is in , depending on income and family size .
by coincidence , an mp with a non-working partner and two children would be in the fourth quintile .
distributional impact chart

obr chief robert chote has predicted that the stamp duty reforms will push up the cost of less expensive homes , echoing earlier warnings ( see 2.58pm onwards ) katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) obr 's chote : stamp duty change shd boost transactions as net giveaway .
prices should rise for houses where duty cut so effectively it 's a boost for those who already own a house , not simply those trying to buy one .
katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) would n't be an obr briefing without chote 's `` flamethrower of uncertainty '' on whether govt will meet fiscal mandate
back at the obr press conference , robert chote confirms that the delays to rolling out the government 's universal credit will cut spending ( as we flagged up earlier ) .

sam coates times ( @ samcoatestimes ) obr makes clear that osborne banking decent savings from further decision to delay universal credit- see delay chart steve hawkes ( @ steve hawkes ) obr says govt is saying more than £ 1 billion over next three years because of `` further delays to roll out of universal credit '' # oops this is covered on page 156 of the obr 's report , where the watchdog says : compared to previous assumptions the combination of the move to dwp 's preferred profile and our 6-month delay to non-jsa cases has the effect of migrating about 2.2 million fewer people onto universal credit in 2016-17 , 2.9 million in 2017-18 , and 1.6 million in 2018-19 than in march , leaving some recipients of esa and tax credits to migrate later .
here 's a guardian video with extracts from george osborne 's speech .

documents.title: small print alert : osborne planning a levy on tobacco firms
text: in politics , if your opponents have a good idea , the best option is often to pinch it wholesale .
and that is what george osborne seems to be doing with labour 's levy on tobacco companies ( which labour announced at the 2014 party conference , and plans to use to help improve the nhs ) .
osborne did not mention this in his speech , perhaps because labour mps would have jeered at him if he had done .
but it 's there , on page 62 of the autumn statement green book .
as smoking imposes costs on society , and the government believes it is therefore fair to ask the tobacco industry to make a greater contribution .
the government will shortly launch a consultation on introducing a levy on tobacco manufacturers and importers .
if you 're just joining us , you might find this summary helpful : autumn statement 2014 at a glance : eight key points

confirmation that the deficit will be up a bit '' in the current financial year : katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) explaining higher borrowing forecast for uk this year , obr 's chote refers to growth in jobs skewed to low earners

problems in the eurozone are the biggest threat to the recovery : katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) obr key risks to its growth outlook , include troubles in eurozone and a failure of productivity to recover in uk
and my colleague libby brooks has sent me some reaction from scotland .

the snp 's deputy leader and treasury spokesperson stewart hosie mp wasted no time in linking the chancellor 's statement to the argument for more powers for the scottish parliament , responding : austerity has failed .
that is why we must have full economic decision making power in scotland to deliver prosperity with a purpose - to grow the economy and deliver real social justice . ''

the scottish green party 's co-convenor patrick harvie msp likewise condemned osborne 's delusional optimism '' about the state of the economy , saying it proved how out of touch westminster politicians really are .
the solution ?

with miliband and balls still signed up to the austerity agenda it is increasingly clear we need more green voices at westminster to argue for a balanced economy , with better jobs and decent public services . ''

neither mention osborne 's measures to encourage investment in the north sea oil and gas industry , but they 've been welcomed by the sector which called for a north sea tax break last week after a survey suggested confidence was at its lowest level for six years .
uk inflation will soon fall below 1 % , the obr says .
katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) boe governor carney looks likely to be writing to chancellor soon to explain low inflation .

obr sees infl low of 0.9 % early next year ( the bank of england is charged with keeping inflation close to 2 % , and must explain itself if the consumer prices index strays by more than one percentage point )
george osborne has launched a driverless car initiative .
my colleague samuel gibbs has the details .

the chancellor announced the winning cities for the government 's driverless car funding competition , which will see consortia in greenwich , coventry and milton keynes and bristol given the green light to conduct driverless car trials on public roads from 1 january .

the three cities will be awarded up to £ 19m to conduct the trials , including the original £ 10m announced in july by the business secretary vince cable , and a further £ 9m from bis , dft and the treasury .

transport research laboratory in greenwich will test an automated transport system in london , ove arup will trial road-going cars and autonomous transport in coventry and milton keynes , and bristol will host driverless cars and pods in the city centre .
the projects are expected to last between 18 and 36 months .
the uk is a world-leader in the development of driverless technology , and today 's announcement will see driverless cars take to city streets from 1 january , '' said cable .
this not only puts us at the forefront of this transformational technology but it also opens up new opportunities for our economy and society . ''
here 's natalie bennett , the green party leader , on the autumn statement .
the many problems with this autumn statement start with its foundations .
osborne is continuing the demonstrably false claim that our deficit problems can be blamed on government spending and welfare .
but what got us into 'this mess ' is the fraud , errors and mismanagement of the corrupt and still out-of-control financial sector .

but to admit that would require george osborne to explain why after more than four years in government he has not delivered the urgent action needed is to tackle the still out-of-control sector , the still too-big-to-fail banks and its hulking dominance of our imbalanced economy that sucks capital and skilled people into the city and away from places where they could be helping to improve the wellbeing of all .

documents.title: obr press conference
text: the office for budget responsibility has begun its press conference on the autumn statement .
its chief , robert chote , begins by explaining that the watchdog sees a sharper slowdown next year .

and there is major uncertainty over uk productivity and earnings economics reporter katie allen is there , tweeting the key points : katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) obr 's chote says their forecast somewhat weaker than bank of england for growth as he presents obr outlook katie allen ( @ katieallengdn ) obr 's chote : consumer spending still main driver of growth so far this year but biz investment now revised up # as2014
phil aldrick of the times is also struck by the scale of cuts still to come : philip aldrick ( @ philaldrick ) hidden away in the obr is another £ 14.5bn cut in departmental spending in 2019/20 .
huge .
is osborne going to close down the treasury ?

documents.title: small print alert : 60 % of the cuts are still to come , says the obr
text: more grim forecasts from the obr .
towards the back of its report ( pdf ) , from page 147 , the obr tries to assess what the government 's plans mean for public spending over the next five years .
it says 60 % of the cuts are yet to come .

the figures imply that roughly 40 per cent of the total implied cut in day-to­ day public services spending between 2009-10 and 2019-20 will have taken place over this parliament , with roughly 60 per cent to come in the next .
and most of the implied spending cuts in the next parliament lie beyond the period for which there are currently firm departmental plans .

and there is a chart setting out what the implied spending cuts in terms of resource departmental expenditure limits ( day to day government spending , but not welfare ) means in terms of spending per head .
the obr says there is an implied cut from £ 5,650 per head in 2009-10 to £ 3,880 in 2019-20 .
public spending cuts
duncan stott , director of pricedout - the campaign for affordable house prices - also fears today 's stamp duty changes will inflate house prices .

a house sold at the current average price of £ 273,000 will now be liable for £ 4,540 less stamp duty , but since sellers want to maximise the sale price of their property , they will expect buyers to pay this money to the house instead you have to wonder whether george osborne is trying to stoke up house prices in advance of next year 's general election .
pricedout argues that britain needs wider reform to property taxation , including a comprehensive revaluation and rebanding of council tax . ''
the changes in stamp duty may drive up house prices .
professor michael ben-gad of city university in london predicts that sellers will slap a few thousand pounds more on their asking price , now that buyers have more cash to spend .
the short-run impact is likely to be a rise in house prices , because the immediate supply of housing is inelastic and sellers will pocket most of the tax reduction .
in the long-run , lower taxation should help spur a bit more house building and so in a few years ' time , buyers may see some benefit .
of course at the very top , there will be an increase , so this is one way of undermining labour 's mansion tax argument . ''

documents.title: obr says some welfare reforms saving less money than expected
text: the obr also said that some of iain duncan smith 's welfare reforms are saving less money than expected .

ongoing reforms to incapacity and disability benefits are unlikely to save as much money over the next few years as we thought in march , but from 2016-17 the impact is broadly offset by lower expected inflation ( which reduces the amount by which most benefits would be uprated ) and by another delay to the rollout of universal credit .

documents.title: small print alert : public spending set to fall to lowest level since world war two
text: and here 's another obr revelation .
it says that public spending , as a percentage of gdp , will fall to its lowest level for 80 years by the end of this decade according to the treasury 's plans .

total public spending is now projected to fall to 35.2 per cent of gdp in 2019-20 , taking it below the previous post-war lows reached in 1957-58 and 1999-00 to what would probably be its lowest level in 80 years .
spending as a % of gdp
here 's len mccluskey , the unite general secretary , on the autumn statement .
the vast majority of people listening to george osborne talking about an economic recovery will think it 's a figment of his imagination .

this is a phoney recovery , built on dangerous levels of consumer debt that are the highest across europe , run up as people borrow to get by because his government 's policies have made people poorer , the rich richer and cut income to the treasury .
not only are the people worse off since he took office , but so is the nation .

documents.title: small print alert : further cuts assumed for the next parliament
text: it is a long way ahead , but the autumn statement makes a new assumption for spending in 2019-20 .
it assumes that total government spending will be frozen that year .
in its report , the obr says this implies a big cut to current spending .
the largest single-year effect of a government decision comes via its new assumption for total spending in 2019­ 20 , although this does not appear in the treasury 's table of policy decisions .
this implies another cut in current spending by central government departments in that year equivalent to £ 14.5 billion ( compared to holding spending flat as a share of potential gdp ) .

businesses have generally welcomed the planned review of business rates , with some provisos ( julia kollewe reports ) the british property federation urged that any future changes to the system should not take place purely to help high street retailers to compete with internet outlets , and advised reform should benefit all rate payers , not just a subset of them.james lowman , head of the association of convenience stores , chipped in : local shops will welcome the 2 % cap on rates increases and the extension of the higher threshold for small business rate relief , alongside the increased £ 1,500 rates discount for shops on the high street . ''
the british chambers of commerce added : this iniquitous tax is sapping good companies ' strength year after year , long before they make a single penny in profits . ''

documents.title: small print alert : obr says real earnings wo n't return to pre-crisis levels over next 5 years
text: as usual with a budget or an autumn statement , some of the most interesting revelations are in the office for budget responsibility 's report ( pdf ) .

here is one of them , meaningful real wage growth is expected to resume in 2015 , although the measure of real earnings in our forecast does not return to its pre-crisis level within the next five years .
estate agent savills reckons around three quarters of a million home buyers across england will benefit from the stamp duty changes .
around 17,000 high-end transactions will incur more tax , though .

this chart shows how most housebuyers will pay less , while those buying a £ 1m+plus house will pay progressively more.. lucian cook , savills uk head of residential research , says those in london and the south east will benefit most : in particular , first time buyers and second steppers will find it easier to raise the deposit needed to obtain mortgage finance , removing one of the major hurdles in the current market .
at the other end of the market , we estimate that around £ 2.2 billion of stamp duty receipts will come from property worth more than £ 2million .
this means that one third of total stamp duty revenues from residential property will be generated by fewer than 5,000 sales - less than half a percent of all transactions .
this should put an end to any argument that these properties are under-taxed and further significantly undermines any case for a mansion tax . ''

the tuc , however , are not impressed ; general secretary frances o'grady fears eye-watering '' cuts after the election : nothing in today 's autumn statement will give britain a pay rise , and conservative plans to effectively outlaw strikes will help make britain permanently low-paid .
wrapping up last year 's infrastructure presents and giving them to us again will not give the economy the extra boost it now needs .
today should have seen policies for growth , but the chancellor has boxed himself in with a rigid and artificial deficit reduction timetable .
if he continues in office that will mean eye-watering spending cuts straight after the election .
these would knock the recovery sideways , deter investment and lead to great damage to our social fabric .
this is economic self-harm , threatening a vicious circle of further decline .
that would be groundhog day all over again - the same mistake that the coalition made in its first two years . ''

the ceo of nationwide , the building society , is pleased , graham beale ( @ bealegj ) nationwide has been campaigning for stamp duty reform for more than a decade so we are delighted with @ twitterid osborne 's announcement today
the autumn statement has not rocked sterling , which is hovering around $ 1.567 .
that 's is a decent sign that there are few major surprises .

nicholas ebisch , currency analyst for caxton fx , explains : fiscal policy specifics seldom have a significant effect on currency markets , unless there is something unexpected and drastic announced , but these announcements today were in line with what the market was expecting .
here are some more statistics on the stamp duty reforms .
people selling homes worth more than £ 1m will pay an extra £ 600m .
but people selling homes worth less than £ 1m will gain £ 1.4bn .
some 98 % of sellers will benefit .
and , even in london , 91 % will benefit , the treasury is saying .
as
the cbi is reacting positively .
this is from john cridland , it 's director general .
these major changes on stamp duty and business rates will be a shot in the arm for families and growing firms as they look towards 2015 .
the targeted focus on enterprise is right , but business innovators would have liked to see more on research and development ( r & d ) to boost uk investment .

international tax rules are in urgent need of updating , but the decision for the uk to go it alone , outside the oecd process , will be a concern for global businesses , and moving the goalposts on offsetting losses risks creating a worrying precedent .
an example of how the stamp duty changes will help some people : steve gardner ( @ stevegardneritv ) i 'm a few days away from exchanging contracts on a flat .
suddenly saved four figures outta nowhere .
john hawksworth , chief economist at pricewaterhousecoopers .
says : austerity still has at least four more years to run to eliminate the budget deficit .
we are in for another parliament of pain , but there could be light at the end of the tunnel by 2020 . ''
the stamp duty changes have hit foxtons , which specialises in high price housing in london and the south .
its shares are down 6 % on worries about the increase in tax on homes over £ 1.5m .

documents.title: stamp duty shake-up , the details
text: the stamp duty changes feel like the big news in today 's autumn statement .

the treasury insists that 98 % of households will benefit ; the big losers are people paying over £ 1m for a house : if you 're buying a home for less than £ 937,500 , you will pay less stamp duty , or the same .
so what 's changed ?
under the old rules , housebuyers paid tax at a single rate on the entire property price .
now you will only pay the rate of tax on the part of the property price within each tax band - like income tax .
under the old rules if you bought a house for £ 185,000 , you would have had to pay 1 % tax on the full amount - a total of £ 1,850 .
under the new rules , for the same property you 'll pay nothing on the first £ 125,000 and 2 % on the remaining £ 60,000 .
this works out as £ 1,200 , a saving of £ 650 , the treasury says ... want more ?
there 's a factsheet here .

airline shares are climbing after george osborne scrapped air passenger duty for children flying out of the country , markets reporter nick fletcher explains : the chancellor abolished the charge for children under 12 from next may and for children under 16 from 2016 .
the tax costs between £ 13 and £ 194 per passenger depending on the flight distance and the class of travel .
the news has lifted british airways owner international airlines group by more than 2 % to 470p and easyjet by the same amount to £ 16.60 .
the cut to stamp duty has benefited housebuilders and property companies , with persimmon up 1.5 % , bovis homes 2.2 % better , zoopla up 3.4 % and countrywide 2.2 % higher .

documents.title: small print alert : obr sees weaker income tax revenues ahead
text: the office for budget responsibility says : despite stronger growth , we have revised up our estimate of the budget deficit this year .
but the budget is still forecast to be back in balance by 2018-19 .
the government is on track to meet its fiscal mandate and the welfare cap , but not its supplementary debt target .
and what 's the cause of this higher borrowing ?
weak tax receipts - particularly from income tax .
and this is likely to get worse over the next five years , not better .
the obr says : this raises borrowing by £ 7.8bn in 2014-15 , rising to £ 25.3bn in 2018-19 .
obr forecasts , autumn statement 2014

shares in unilever , gsk and astrazeneca have all fallen on the chancellor 's announcement of a 25 % google tax '' on multinationals shifting profits out of the uk , our colleague julia kollewe flags up .

neil shah , director of research at edison investment research , said : this new multinationals tax , while clearly aimed at catching uk-generated profits from online operators such as amazon and google , may have unintended consequences on global manufacturers with uk listings from unilever to sabmilller to big pharma .
sky 's business editor ian king says the growth downgrades from 2016 onwards are major , major '' changes , and a worry .

documents.title: small print alert : eu migrant clampdown wo n't save much
text: blocking european migrants from claiming the jobseeker 's allowance may make good headlines ( in some newspapers ) , but it will only save £ 15m a year , at most .
via our datablog editor alberto nardelli : alberto nardelli ( @ albertonardelli ) limiting access to jsa for eu migrants saves a whopping £ 15m
here 's the key table , confirming that britain will borrow over £ 91bn to balance the books this year , down from £ 97.5bn a year ago : .
statement ( the first table is 2013-14 , then 2014-15 etc )
here 's a link to the autumn statement .
news balls has got his hands on the obr 's new economic outlook .
it shows that borrowing over the next two years is actually £ 12.5bn higher than expected in the budget , he declares [ reminder : a lot of data has been revised to meet international standards ] .
there 's a crack about how the chancellor has changed his haircut , but ca n't change his tendency to mislead .
only labour can deliver a fair recovery , he concludes .
the stamp duty reform amounts to a tax cut worth £ 800m , not £ 800,000 , as i posted earlier .
that was a mistake .
sorry .
as
my colleague henry mcdonald says george osborne put a very interesting spin on his offer to let northern ireland have control over corporation tax .
one of the very few issues on which the unionist and nationalist parties agree is a regional special rate to match the irish republic 's low 12.5 % corporation tax rate .

the power-sharing executive at stormont has argued that northern ireland can not compete with the republic in terms of wooing foreign direct investment to the province if corporation tax is double the rate in belfast that it is in dublin .

but george osborne has said there will have to be both legislation in belfast and negotiation with the uk treasury if the northern ireland assembly votes for a special regional rate close to the republic 's 12.5 % .

given that there has been political deadlock between the two major parties - sinn fein and the democratic unionists - over the implementation of treasury-imposed welfare cuts it seems there will be pressure from london that the price of lower corporation tax will be the power-sharing coalition accepting cuts after all .
the royal institution of chartered surveyors in northern ireland has pointed this price up as it reacted to the news from the chancellor .
ben collins , the rcis director in the region , said : the onus is now on the northern ireland executive to demonstrate that it can make progress on key issues like welfare reform . ''

the ulster unionist party echoed this warning stating that the power-sharing executive would have to prove it was able to manage its budget before the treasury would accept northern ireland could set its own corporation tax rate .
balls welcomes the changes to stamp duty ( details are here ) saying the government has belatedly recognised that owners of the most expensive houses are undertaxed .
but today 's measures are n't enough - why not have an annual charge on the highest properties [ ie a mansion tax ] , and fund a £ 2.5bn injection into the health service ?
balls returns to cameron 's mis-step at pmqs , when the pm said the shadow chancellor referred to masosadism '' .
it means someone who enjoys having pain inflicted on them , and inflecting pain on other people , balls explains helpfully .

documents.title: autumn statement - snap political verdict
text: you can see why david cameron was so excited .

even though home ownership has been going down under this government , this remains a nation where home ownership remains an obsession and osborne 's stamp duty reforms , which combine a reasonable-sized tax cut with a common sense modification , are bound to get a terrific write-up in the papers tomorrow .
holding the vote tomorrow also means that labour has just 24 hours to decide whether to support it , although in principle i ca n't see why they would necessarily object .

otherwise , it was a substantial package , much of which has been pre-announced over the last three days , with a surprise near the start , when osborne released the figures on the public finances and claimed the deficit reduction was actually rosier than people expected .
whether those claims will survive scrutiny over the next few hours remains to be seen .
as
ed balls is welcoming some of the measures in the autumn statement , such as the changes to air passenger duty .
but he 's disappointed that the review on business rates wo n't report until 2016 .
growth from 2016 onwards has been revised down 'year after year after year ' ( as flagged up earlier ) .
the shadow chancellor , ed balls , responds , saying parliament must check the full details of the obr 's economic outlook to understand the detail of the autumn statement .
he points out that wage growth has been weaker than expected through the last parliament , creating a squeeze on family budgets creating a shortfall on tax revenues .
balls points out that the government has failed to balance the budget , as promised in 2010 .
next year 's deficit will be £ 75.9bn - showing the books have not been balanced over the parliament , he points out .

documents.title: snap economic verdict
text: there 's not too much to cheer in today 's economic forecasts , despite george osborne 's best efforts to claim a triumph ( and the howls of delight from his backbenchers as he sat down ) the underlying is still pretty rough , implying another dose of austerity in the next parliament .
the chancellor will be chuffed to announce that deficit will fall year-on-year ( to £ 91.3bn , from £ 97bn in 2013-14 ) .
but that 's actually a slightly larger percentage of gdp than forecast in march ( 5.0 % , vs 4.9 % in the budget ) .
jim pickard ( @ pickardje ) so in a nutshell : borrowing this year is £ 5bn more than was hoped in spring but still lower than last year at 97bn to 91bn .
city economists were too gloomy when they predicted it would take another year to eliminate the deficit , it appears .
it vanishes in 2018-19 , in line with the march budget 's forecast .
uk borrowing forecasts , autumn statement 2014 /obr but we 'll need to see what level of cuts the chancellor is planning in the next parliament to achieve that .
and there is bad news in the obr 's growth forecasts .
it has significantly cut its medium-term forecasts : 2016 : down to just 2.2 % , from 2.6 % .

2017 : down to 2.4 % , from 2.6 % 2018 : down to 2.3 % , from 2.5 % that 's the impact of the slowing global economy , and a recognition that some of the recent stronger growth is catch-up '' from the recession .
gw
osborne says people said it was impossible to control the public finances , and cut taxes .
but you can do it if you have a long-term economic plan , he says .
osborne says he is announcing a complete reform of stamp duty .
it is charged on a single-slab rate , he says .
this means a small rise in the house price can lead to a large increase in tax .
it is a badly-designed tax on aspiration '' , he says .
stamp duty to be reformed .
the single-slab '' rate will go , and instead it will be levied at a more gradual rate .
98 % of buyers will benefit .
the reform will cost £ 800m he says .

the new rates will be : nothing on the first £ 125,000 , 2 % on the share above that up to £ 250,000 ; then 5 % on the next slice up to £ 925,000 ; then 10 % on the next slice up to £ 1.5m ; then 12 % on everything above that .
people buying an average house , worth £ 275,000 , will save £ 4,500 .
new rates to come into force from midnight tonight .
mps to vote on the measure tomorrow .
update : the reform will cost £ 800m , not £ 800,000 .
that was a mis-type .
sorry .
i 've corrected the copy .
osborne turns to tax .
the basic rate income tax allowance will rise to £ 10,600 next year , not £ 10,500 as originally planned .
higher-rate taxpayers will also benefit , he says .
we on this side do not sneer at people who want to work hard and get on , he says .
national insurance abolished for young people doing apprenticeships .
osborne confirms that he will scrap the tax on people who pass annuities on to their children .
details of the new pensioner bond will be announced in january .
government will enable isas to be passed on when people die tax-free .
osborne says he will respect the devolution settlement .
northern ireland can get control of corporation tax , provided the treasury can be assured that the northern ireland executive can handle that .
government to legislate before the election to give northern ireland control over corporation tax , provided assurances are given .
government backing the welsh assembly getting control of business rates .
osborne says this makes the case for english votes for english law unanswerable .
the cuts to air passenger duty are pushing up shares in airlines - easyjet has gained 2 % , and british airlines ' parent company iag is up 1.1 % .
richard murphy ( @ richardjmurphy ) this is a bad autumn statement for carbon usage : air passenger duty down and fuel duty frozen # as2014
osborne says there will also be a major new theatre space in manchester .
it will be called the factory , manchester .
anyone who 's a child of the 1980s will support that .
people thought the 10 manchester authorities would never agree to have an overall elected mayor .
but they have done so .
other cities can follow their lead , he says .
osborne mentions his northern powerhouse '' vision and says he is tendering for new carriages for the trans-pennine express and for northern rail .
osborne says britain was yesterday awarded a lead role in exploring mars .
we on this side have often gazed on the barren waste of the red planet , he says .
we have given up hope of finding intelligent life there .
but signs of any life at all would be an advance , he jokes .
osborne says science is a personal priority .
science is crucial to the economic future , he says .
britain has risen from 14th to second in the scientific creativity index .
support for post-graduate degrees will be increased .
student loans worth up to £ 10,000 will be available to all young people taking post-graduate masters degrees .
osborne turns to fuel duty .
fuel duty to stay frozen .
airlines will have to list charges separately from ticket charges , he says .
air passenger duty for children under 12 will be abolished from may next year .
from the following year it will abolished for children under 16 .
small business rate relief to be doubled for another year .
help for the high street increasing by 50 % to £ 1,500 .
osborne says tax breaks have introduced a golden age for the creative industires .
theatre tax break to be extended to orchestras .
children 's animation credit to be introduced .
osborne says mps will be worried to hear that wallace and grommit are being retired because the man doing the voice has retired .
but after next may another candidate will be available .
( that 's a miliband joke . )
osborne turns to bank tax .
limits imposed on bank profits that can be offset .
this will lead to banks paying £ 4bn over five years , he says .
further tax measures will raise £ 2.8bn , he says .
non-dom charges will be raised for people who have been in the uk for more than 12 years .
osborne says all these charges will raise £ 9bn over five years .
the richest 20 % will contribute more than the remaining 80 % put together , osborne says .
our datablog team explain why the original 2010 target of eliminating the deficit this parliament has been missed : why has george osborne missed the deficit target ?
osborne says he is turning from those who pay too much tax to those who pay too little .
a 25 % tax on profits being introduced on multinationals who shift profits out of the uk .
this will raise £ 1bn over five years .
osborne says his message is clear ; he believes in low taxes , but those taxes must be paid .
osborne says the end of military operations in afghanistan is saving the treasury £ 200m this year .
the inheritance tax exemption will be extended to aid workers who lose their lives in emergencies .
he says the treasury is repaying the national debt incurred to pay for the first world war .
a cathedral renovation fund will be extended .
and there will be support for air ambulances .
they will get refunded vat .
and hos charities will also get a vat refund .
osborne says the obr forecast will show net payments to the eu falling this year , next year and over the next five years .
the new growth figures .
/obr
osborne says crime is down , and satisfaction with local government services is up .
that shows that budgets can be cut , he says .
he says there will be further departmental savings in the next parliament .
the hutton public sector pensions reforms will continue , saving an extra £ 1.3bn , he says .
osborne says the obr will report that the government is on cap to meet the welfare cap commitment .
total welfare spending is due to be £ 1bn lower than forecast in the budget , he says .
and he says he has made clear ( at the tory conference ) that he wants to freeze working age benefits for two years .

the weak inflation predicted by the obr should help wages rise faster than prices through the decade : hm treasury ( @ hmtreasury ) 'the @ twitterid uk predict that meaningful real wage growth will up through next year and grow above inflation for the next 5 years ' # as2014
osborne says he will be spending £ 10bn less this year than in his original spending plans .
some of that underspend will go into the nhs .
that will be an extra £ 2bn a year .
not money that busts our plan , but money available because we have a plan , he says .
osborne also confirms that he will spend £ 1.1bn on improving gp services .
mps to be asked to vote on a new charter of budget responsibility ( setting deficit reduction targets ) next year .
so that is not what the mystery vote tomorrow night will be about .
ladbrokes will be paying out to anyone who bet that osborne would say long-term economic plan '' .
it 's working , the chancellor says .

so , those city economists who reckoned the deficit targets would slip by a year were too pessimistic , but we 'll need to scrutinise the obr 's report for full details faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) brilliantly confusing from osborne dancing through those numbers must always wait till we get the actual numbers
osborne address the question why the public finances are better than expected .
tax receipts are lower than expected , he says .
but interest payments are also lower .
osborne turns to debt .
he says it is coming down faster than forecast .
national debt will be 80.4 % of gdp this year , he says .
it will peak at 81.1 % next year , he says , then go down to 80.7 % in 2016 , then 78. % , then 76.2 % , then 72.8 % in 2019 .
osborne turns to the deficit .
borrowing is falling , he says .
towards the end of the forecast , borrowing is even lower than expected .
that is because the obr has revised its methodology , he says .
borrowing forecast to be £ 91.3bn this year , down from £ 97.5bn forecast .
then it will be £ 75bn , then £ 40.9bn , then £ 14.5bn , then a surplus of £ 4bn in 2018-19 .
in 2019-20 there will be a surplus of £ 23bn , he says .
osborne says the obr predicts that meaningful real wage growth '' will up next year and then continue , above inflation , for five years .
the obr has revised down its inflation forecast , he says .
inflation forecast to be 1.5 % this year , 1.2 % next year and 1.7 % the year after
world first ( @ world first ) u.k. 2015 gdp growth forecast revised to 2.4 % from 2.3 %
osborne says the obr has revised down its unemployment forecasts .
for every day this government has been in office , 1,000 new jobs have been created .
britain 's long-term economic plan is working .
( ladbrokes can start paying out . )
osborne says 85 % of jobs are full time .
and the gender pay gap has fallen to its lowest level in history .
that is progressive politics in action .
osborne turns to the uk growth forecasts .
growth forecast for this year now 3 % , up from 2.7 % in march and 2.4 % last year .
osborne contrasts this with france , and says those who want to follow france ( ie , labour ) are wrong .
growth forecast to be 2.4 % next year , 2.2 % in 2016 , 2.4 % in 2017 , and 2.3 % in 2018 and 2019 .
osborne announces a £ 45m package to boost exports .
osborne turns to the future .
the warning lights are flashing , he says .
obr has revised down its forecast for global growth , this year and ever year .
osborne says he backs aspiration .
turning to the obr 's report , he says new statistical standards have changed the assessement of the economy .
there was no recession in this parliament , no double-dip recession , he says .
the economy has grown 8 % this parliament .
business investment has risen 27 % this parliament .
osborne says the deficit is still too high .
today 's autumn statement will , overall , tighten taxes slightly , he says .
it wo n't be a giveaway .
osborne says growth is higher , unemployment is falling , inflation is down and the deficit is being cut .
the choice is whether to stay the course , or squander this .
osborne says he says stay the course .

documents.title: george osborne 's autumn statement
text: five minutes late , george osborne is starting .
he says four years ago he presented the accounts of an economy in crisis .
now it is the fastest-growing of any major economy in the world .
is this george osborne telling the speaker to get on with it ?
george osborne ( @ george0sborne ) it 's time for the # autumnstatement
it turns out that masosadism really does exist - at least according to the urban dictionary .
perhaps david cameron is more racy than we realise .
as
labour 's nic dakin asks cameron why the government has failed on immigration and the deficit .
cameron says labour left the coalition with a huge problem , and is now complaining it has not been cleared up quickly enough .
david cameron set the tone for today 's autumn statement a fortnight ago , when he warned that red warning lights were flashing over the global economy .

we 're about to find out if the office for budget responsibility agrees , as newsnight 's duncan weldon points out : duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) couple of things to watch out for today : obr forecasts for inflation - should be lower and their crucial estimate of the output gap .
duncan weldon ( @ duncanweldon ) also worth looking to see how the obr revise their estimates of world economic growth .
how bright are the warning lights flashing ?
norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) george osborne reading and re-hearsing lines from his # autumnstatement speech during # pmqs
labour 's chris bryant thinks something is wrong with george osborne .
chris bryant ( @ chrisbryantmp ) george osborne actually looks unwell .
labour 's dennis skinner asks if cameron is proud of the fact that he has added £ 430bn to the national debt , which is more than all the labour chancellors this century .
( i think he meant last century . )
you ca n't blame labour for that .
oh yes i can , says cameron .
the coalition inherited a failing economy , he says .
cameron says labour mps are now suddenly interested in the deficit .
the government took tough decisions , cutting some departments by 20 % .
labour opposed them all , he says .
david cameron 's hint about good news in the autumn statement has given the pound a teensy nudge higher , traders say .
sterling is now up 0.2 % against the us dollar , at $ 1.567 - only a small move .
gw joe bond ( @ joe trading ) cable trading session highs ( 1.5670 ) in anticipation of the # autumnstatement slight tick higher on camerons hint on deficit
labour 's mary glindon asks why the government is borrowing £ 4bn more than last year .
cameron says that is because of the mess left by labour .
this week ed balls said he would be tough on the deficit and tough on the causes of the deficit '' , cameron says .
since balls himself was the cause of it , this is the first example of political maso-sadism , he says .
john bercow , the speaker , says mps know what cameron meant .
in his subsequent answer , cameron says he meant to say masochism .
we all know balls can dish it out but ca n't take it , he says .
now we know balls likes taking it too , he jokes .

documents.title: snap pmqs verdict
text: snap pmqs verdict : more interesting than usual , and ed miliband 's anthology of broken cameron promises was rather effective .
it was also telling how miliband presented these not simply as broken promises , but as sincerity indicators ( did he mean it ? ) .
there is a difference between lying and breaking a promise , and miliband is trying to brand cameron as a liar .

but by the end of the day these exchanges will be forgotten , apart , perhaps , from cameron 's intriguing teaser , about how the autumn statement will leave miliband looking as awkward as he was eating that bacon sandwich .
i 've never heard quite such a cocky pre-budget ( or autumn statement ) boast from the despatch box .
as
robert peston ( @ peston ) big hint by @ twitterid cameron that deficit forecast miss this year could be balanced by improved forecasts for coming years .
# autumnstatement
miliband says cameron has been visiting the david mellor school of charm .
what about cameron 's promise on the deficit .
he said he would balance the books in five years ' time .
did he mean it ?
cameron says the deficit is down by a third .
he wo n't reveal what is in the autumn statement .
but he in a moment or two , miliband will be looking as awkward as when he ate that bacon sandwich .
if we are talking about predictions , let 's remember miliband 's prediction that 1m jobs would go .
labour said there would be a lost decade .
they have been wrong on every economic issue .
miliband says cameron has turned breaking promises into an art form .
people know what cameron says something , he does not mean it .
cameron says no one will forget that labour sold the gold , broke the economy and bankrupted the economy .
still they sit there , hopeless and unelectable . ''
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) pm is boasting about the economic numbers better than expected ?
miliband says cameron should be admitting that he broke his promise .
and what did cameron say to a nurses conference before the election .
there will be no more of those pointless reorganisations '' , cameron said .
did cameron mean that ?
cameron says there are more doctors , more nurses and more patients treated .
he says he has a list of miliband 's promises .
there is a lot of jeering .
cameron says he has all day .
and he 's looking forward to what comes next .
cameron says milband promised a graduate tax , an alternative policy review , and a list of business people he had dinner with .
where is that ?
miliband says the 2010 conservative manifesto promised an economy where stands of living rise .
when he said it , did he mean it ?
cameron says 20m people have had their taxes cut .
the minimum wage has been increaesed .
and people in work are seeing their pay go up by 4 % .
mrs brown 's boys was a comedy .
mr brown 's boys is a tragedy .
ed miliband says cameron said earlier this year : woe betide the politician who makes big promises and than says i did not mean it . ''
has he done that ?
cameron says he has kept his promise to get unemployment down , and make britain a good place to do business .
miliband says cameron has broken his promise on immigration .
in his contract with the british people , cameron said the people should vote him out if he did not deliver .
did he mean it .
cameron says he has cut immigration from outside the eu by 23 % .
labour put immigration up as an act of policy , he says .
david cameron at pmqs .
news
labour 's robert flello says cameron promised to balance the books by 2015 .
but the deficit has barely been touched .
does n't the country need a labour government ?
cameron says the deficit is down by a third , because the government has taken tough decisions .
all of those were opposed by labour , he says .

documents.title: pmqs
text: pmqs has started .
the treasury seems to be firming up the stamp duty reform story .

nick robinson ( @ bbcnickrobinson ) could soon be cheaper to buy a cheaper house & more expensive to buy a pricier one as @ twitterid osborne looks set to reform stamp duty tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) looks like stamp duty reform will indeed be osborne 's autumn statement rabbit to shoot labour 's mansion tax fox .
@ twitterid 's top scoop .
it 's also pmqs today , of course .
i wo n't be covering the whole thing as i usually do , but i will cover the exchanges between david cameron and ed miliband , and any autumn statement-related questions .

dave prentis , general secretary of unison , is urging george osborne to offer ordinary workers some respite : people simply ca n't afford to live on their wages and many have had to borrow more and get second jobs to make ends meet - people working round the clock to ensure they can keep their homes , pay their bills and feed their families .
unison - the union ( @ unisontweets ) unison gen sec says # autumnstatement is # osborne 's last chance to ditch # austerity : # as2014
william hague , the leader of the commons , is making a business statement after the autumn statement .
that will , presumably , clear up the mystery about the vote that has been timetabled for tomorrow evening .
there is speculation that george osborne is going to stage a commons vote on balancing the budget by 2017-18 , in the hope of getting labour to vote against .
as
the child poverty action group is predicting one topic that wo n't be in the autumn statement .
cpag ( @ cpaguk ) # autumnstatement starts soon - has n't included a mention of child poverty since 2012
one note of caution , the deficit figures in today 's autumn statement probably wo n't be directly comparable to the numbers in march 's budget .

britain changed the way it calculates the public finances this summer , to meet international standards , as scotiabank explains here : sam coates times ( @ samcoatestimes ) autumn statement warning : definition of psnb / deficit changed in september & not comparable to budget .
scotiabank :
sky 's faisal islam is complaining about the size of the temporary bbc autumn statement studio on abingdon green , outside the houses of parliament .
faisal islam ( @ faisalislam ) state broadcaster has built a giant spaceship at front of parliament blocking views , casting large shadow
here 's the bbc 's robin brant on george osborne as he headed for his car .
robin brant ( @ robindbrant ) osbo departs hmt for commons .
instant analysis of face : no smile , sombre look , warning lights on the dashboard etc # autumnstatement and my colleague claire phipps adds this .
claire phipps ( @ claire phipps ) george osborne looks cold walking to his car .
that 's because it 's not autumn # autumnstatement

documents.title: george osborne heads to parliament
text: the chancellor has just left the treasury and boarded his government car for the short drive to the house of commons .
no trace of a smile..
labour 's stewart wood has given a christmas flavour to his autumn statement tweeting .
stewart wood ( @ stewartwood ) somewhere in the westminster ether today you 'll hear the ghost of osborne past whispering : `` it 's all about wiping out the deficit by 2015 '' .
the evening standard has up on the reports that george osborne is going to reform stamp duty in the autumn statement .
( see 9.20am . )
the chancellor was expected to make the tax on homebuyers slightly fairer by smoothing the cliff edge '' effect of sudden increases when prices go into new bands .
he may even reduce stamp duty for cheaper homes , but experts think few properties in london would be priced low enough to qualify .
and there was speculation that londoners could end up paying more than ever , with talk in westminster circles of making stamp duty more progressive '' so that it hits high-value homes harder .
the obvious point to make about this move is that it would go some way towards neutralising the attractions of the labour/lib dem mansion tax plan .
( and , contrary to what myleene klass would have you believe , polls suggest the mansion tax is popular , even in london - pdf . )
sterling is already hovering near a 15-month low , and could come under pressure today if the borrowing figures in the autumn statement disappoints the city .
joe bond of broker abshire smith reckons : during the speech any unexpected announcements could move the pound .
the statement needs to be business and deficit friendly to benefit the pound .
one pound is currently worth $ 1.565 .
other economists have suggested that sterling could fall in the run-up to next may 's general election , especially if a hung parliament looks certain .
gw

health spending has been ring-fenced during this parliament , along with spending on schools and international aid , and all main parties have indicated that they intend to protect health spending in the next parliament .
but kwasi kwarteng , a conservative mp and a member of the conservative free enterprise group , thinks that pledge might have to be abandoned .
the independent today splashes on comments to this effect he made at a recent institute of economic affairs thinktank .

kwarteng said : we have always been very clear that deficit reduction is absolutely important and if you are going to reduce the deficit then everything should be put on the table and considered equally .
it 's common knowledge that there has been a consensus on international aid that we should ring-fence that , [ and ] on health spending .
i think that consensus will be under a lot of strain given the budget realities .
that will force change in the political discussion .
if you 're looking for a guide as to quite how tight the spending cuts will be in the next parliament , this resolution foundation report is excellent .
as
britain 's failure to get its deficit down has n't hit its borrowing costs .
10-year gilts are changing hands at a yield ( or interest rate ) of just 1.975 % this morning .
ed conway ( @ edconwaysky ) no wonder @ twitterid osborne is paying off the war loan .

uk govt is currently able to borrow at a rate of less than 2 % the chancellor ca n't repeat his boast that britain is borrowing more cheaply than germany , though , as 10-year bunds are yielding just 0.74 % - pushed down by fears of deflation in the eurozone and the prospect of the european central bank launching a full-scale bond-buying programme .
gw
according to the new statesman 's george eaton , a labour mini-shuffle ( very mini ) is underway .
george eaton ( @ georgeeaton ) breaking : new shadow attorney general is lord bach , labour source tells me .
1/2 george eaton ( @ georgeeaton ) more on mini labour reshuffle : chris bryant set to move from shadow dwp to shadow dcms , source says .

turning away from the autumn statement for a moment , tomorrow the guardian is hosting an online hustings for the three candidates in the scottish labour leadership election , jim murphy , neil findlay and sarah boyack .
you can read more about it , and post questions in advance , here .

on budget day it 's up to the leader of the opposition to respond , but the autumn statement is viewed , in commons terms , as just a conventional ministerial statement and so the labour response will come from george osborne 's shadow , ed balls .
last year his performance was judged to be quite poor .
he was heckled very badly by tory mps .
doubtless he will receive similar barracking today .
but if you want to know his message , he has already put it out in the form of a news release .
here 's an extract .
david cameron and george osborne have now failed every test and broken every promise they made on the economy .
they promised living standards would rise , but while millionaires have got a huge tax cut working people are £ 1600 a year worse off under the tories .
this cost-of-living crisis is why the chancellor will have to admit he has broken his promise to balance the books by next year .
the ft 's giles wilkes has identified a government hashtag split .
giles wilkes ( @ gilesyb ) signs of a serious downing street split as @ twitterid cameron and @ twitterid osborne use different hashtags for # autumnstatement # as2014 .
douglas carswell was n't particularly complimentary about the treasury when he was perched on the government benches .
now he 's clad in ukip purple , and blasting george osborne for failing by any objective yardstick '' to get a grip on the public finances .

he writes that tomorrow 's autumn statement will be full of brownian-style bluster '' , with clever wheezes and gimmicks '' designed to distract from the true douglas carswell mp ( @ douglascarswell ) mr osborne has failed to reduce deficit as fast as he promised .
he 's not even reduced it as fast as gordon brown promised .
# continuitybrown douglas carswell mp ( @ douglascarswell ) big infrastructure projects and spending funded by more debt .
# continuitybrown
tim worstall at forbes has a good post explaining why george osborne 's claim to be paying off debt from the first world war ( see 8.58am ) are not quite what they seem .
note that he really has said pay off '' there and that 's the part that just is n't so .
a government that is borrowing £ 100 billion a year and change is n't paying off any debt whatsoever .
it 's just swapping one debt for another .
by the definitions that osborne is using , in fact that wwi debt was all paid off in 1927 .
which , given that we 've still got bonds around relating to that debt shows that a refinancing is not actually the same as paying off a debt .
back to those rumours of stamp duty reform .
these charts show how the current 'slab system ' is particularly lucrative in and around the capital : ..

they 're via savills , the estate agent , who would be very pleased to see stamp duty revised : first time buyers across london and second steppers across the whole of the south of england , see a sizeable chunk of their equity siphoned off to the treasury , making it much harder for them to raise the deposit needed to get the mortgage they require to get on or trade up the housing ladder .
gw
here are two more stories from today 's paper about announcements coming up in the autumn statement .
the daily mail says george osborne is going to scrap business taxes in their existing form .
business taxes that have existed since tudor times could be scrapped .

chancellor george osborne will today put reform of despised business rates - and more cheap loans for small firms - at the centre of his plans to secure the recovery retailers have long been pushing for reform of rates - which have existed in various forms since 1601 - to ease the pressure on the high street .
sources suggest that moving away from a charge based on the rateable value of a commercial property to a modern alternative - such as a sales tax - is being considered .
the smallest businesses could be exempted altogether .
the sun says osborne will present a budget for white van man , scrapping the fair fuel stabiliser '' .
the fair fuel stabiliser is something that osborne actually introduced himself , in 2011 , to replace labour 's fuel escalator .
the autumn statement will be an exercise in sowing a silk purse out of a sow 's ear '' , says top currency strategy kit juckes , of french bank societe generale .
the big problem is the budget arithmetic , as strong growth has failed to translate into strong income tax receipts due to the shifting nature of the jobs market .
the chancellor needs to promise largesse ahead of next year 's election but smoke , mirrors and optimistic forecasts will be needed .
we 'll do our best to blow away the smoke and smash those mirrors .
gw
we mentioned earlier that weak wage growth means tax receipts have been persistently disappointing since 2010 , pushing the deficit over target .
this chart shows the scale of the shortfall ( the gap between the two brown lines ) : .

that 's via berenberg bank chief economist , rob wood , who says that any rabbit that comes bounding from the chancellor 's hat is unlikely to be clutching paws full of cash '' : first , despite holding down spending , government borrowing remains stubbornly high as tax revenues undershoot expectations .
second , the government already plans to take day-to-day spending on public services and administration to its lowest share of gdp since world war ii .
within that health and education are protected from real terms cuts , meaning other departments have to shoulder very large real budget reductions .
that could worsen a little today .
gw
one piece of good economic news this morning : britain 's service sector grew at a faster pace in november , with firms reporting a in business and new orders .
that suggests the uk economy is ending the year quite well .
more here .
gw
and george osborne has been tweeting about his autumn statement too .
george osborne ( @ george osborne ) can announce we 'll repay in full our # ww1 debt.in today 's # as2014 i 'll set out how we will secure the economy & stay on course to prosperity
ladbrokes have gone mad .

like other bookies , they offer odds on phrases that will appear in the chancellor 's autumn statement speech - more for publicity purposes , i guess , than as a revenue-raising venture - and this morning they have sent out their list .
here are the favourites .

1/10 long term economic plan 1/3 immigration evs stonehenge evs bringing down the deficit 6/4 white van 2/1 tough decisions 3/1 hard choices the surprise is that they are even taking bets on long-term economic plan '' .
i do n't bet , or offer tips , but this is such a dead-cert that it amounts to giving money away .
if anyone has a spare £ 1tr to bet , they could nip down to ladbrokes and pay off the deficit by the end of the day .
as
britain faces the prospect of tax rises in the next parliament , not the tax cuts promised at the last conservative party conference .
so says george magnus , a well-respected city economist , who warns that britain 's public finances are on shaky ground '' .

given the hefty deficits expected over the next five years ( see earlier post ) , it is pure economic sophistry '' and deception '' to tell a public tired of austerity that there are tax reductions around the corner , he argues .
magnus reckons that public borrowing from now until 2020 could be £ 60bn more than planned a year ago .

the rise of automation , he points out , is a key factor pushing down wage growth : the weakness of tax revenues is an important part of the reason reflecting continued stagnation in aggregate wages and salary formation , and the disproportionate growth in low wage , low skill jobs .
this is a structural , and increasingly digital technology phenomenon , which will not diminish quickly without policy interventions , which are barely discussed .
more here : uk autumn statement throw a blanket over the tax rise we know is coming .
gw
and here 's a guardian autumn statement video explaining how companies like google avoid tax .
as patrick wintour and larry elliott explain in today 's guardian , george osborne will give details of how he plans to tackle this kind of tax avoidance .
at the conservative party conference , aides were referring to it as the google tax .
david cameron has been tweeting about the autumn statement .
david cameron ( @ david cameron ) in today 's # autumnstatement @ twitterid osborne will show our long term economic plan is working and why we must stay the course to prosperity .
ken clarke .
last night , former chancellor ken clarke argued that britain would be in a bad way '' if if osborne had n't abandoned his goal of eliminating the deficit this parliament .
clarke told newsnight that : we had a target of getting rid of the deficit in this parliament .
i actually think that although it perhaps was n't entirely planned it was very sensible that we did n't do it that quickly . ''
had we tried getting rid of the whole deficit , 'let 's charge ahead ' , we would not be in the state we are .
we would be in a bad way . ''
there 's speculation this morning that the chancellor will announce a shake-up of the uk 's stamp duty system in the autumn statement .
this could end the current 'slab system ' , where housebuyers pay 1 % on purchases between £ 125,000 and £ 250,000 , 3 % between £ 250,000 and £ 500,000 and 4 % for more than £ 500,000 .
this effectively widens the gaps on the housing ladder .

chris tinker of building group crest nicholson has welcomed the idea , telling bloomberg tv that : anything that was seamless , progressive , gave a smoother tax flow would be very welcome to the housing industry . ''
osborne could also potentially announce higher charges for more expensive properties , in a response to labour 's proposed mansion tax .
gw
steve hawkes ( @ steve hawkes ) hmt announce chancellor to repay first world war debt , could lead to a few jokes later today about time it will take to clear the deficit
we 're expecting the chancellor to promise 'urgent action ' to prevent multinational firms avoiding paying their fair share of tax ; perhaps spurred by the recent luxleaks revelations ?

as the guardian 's front-page story explains : george osborne will take the first steps to redeem his pledge to tackle corporate tax abuse by big technology multinationals in the autumn statement , which will see a final admission that the government failed to fulfil its central economic mission of eliminating the underlying deficit by 2014-15 .

the chancellor is expected to have to concede that net borrowing for the year will reach about £ 90bn - greater than the £ 86.5bn predicted at the time of the last budget - but in a statement shaped by the continued constraints on the public finances , osborne will try to highlight plans to take urgent action to clamp down on tax loopholes exploited by technology firms such as amazon and google , even though the most effective action requires international agreement .

in what is also expected to be a highly politicised pre-election address , the chancellor will insist that the country faces a stark choice between staying the course to prosperity '' or instead squandering the economic security we have gained and go back to the disastrous decisions on spending and borrowing and welfare that got us into this mess '' .

more here : george osborne on offensive over tax abuse but admits deficit target missed nick sutton ( @ suttonnick ) wednesday 's guardian front page : osborne on the offensive over tax and deficit # tomorrowspaperstoday # bbcpapers
we 've pulled together the six key charts that explains the state of the uk economy .

autumn statement : six graphs you need to see it includes a reminder that george osborne 's 2011 pledge to create a 'march of the makers ' has stumbled a little ; the services sector is the only part of the economy that 's larger than before the 2008 recession : uk economy , by section /obr
neville chamberlain .
press agency/getty images we already have one announcement from the government this morning - britain is paying off the debt incurred from the first world war .
the treasury will redeem the outstanding £ 1.9 billion of debt from 3½ % war loan on 9 march 2015 .
this bond was issued in 1932 by neville chamberlain , the chancellor of the day , to reduce the costs of servicing the national debt .
the plan is to replace these legacy bonds with newly issued debt , at lower rates than the old war debt .
george osborne says : this is a moment for britain to be proud of .
we can , at last , pay off the debts britain incurred to fight the first world war .
it is a sign of our fiscal credibility and it 's a good deal for this generation of taxpayers .
it 's also another fitting way to remember that extraordinary sacrifice of the past .
hm treasury ( @ hmtreasury ) chancellor to repay the nation 's first world war debt more details in our business liveblog :

documents.title: autumn statement : economic preview
