text: the economic section of today 's autumn statement will bring little festive cheer , and should confirm that george osborne has missed the targets set back in 2010 .
the chancellor will doubtless do his best to sprinkle some glitter over the numbers , though .
the growth forecast for 2014 may be revised a little higher , to 3 % , allowing george osborne to boast that the uk is the best-performing member of the g7 major nations this year .
but that rise in gdp is stubbornly refusing to delivering improvement elsewhere .
instead , the public finances are suffering from persistently weak tax receipts , partly because so many of the jobs created since the last recession are low-paid .
which means more pain on the fiscal side .
uk income tax receipts have consistently missed forecast since 2010 , ey george osborne is expected to admit that this year 's deficit will be higher than the £ 86.6bn planned in march .
the bill could reach £ 95bn , economists reckon , close to last year 's £ 97.5bn .
that would be almost £ 60bn more than the £ 37bn forecast in the june 2010 budget , a reminder of how the government has missed its original deficit targets .
the independent office for budget responsibility ( created by george osborne in 2010 ) will issue its latest economic and fiscal outlook once the chancellor 's speech is over .
the obr may well dampen its growth forecasts for the next few years , and predict higher borrowing levels .
that would mean the chancellor will not achieve his target of delivering a surplus in 2018-19 , as proudly announced in march .
that may not happen until 2019-20 .
as the ey item club puts it : the autumn statement provides one of the last opportunities for the chancellor to use fiscal policy to try to gain votes .
but the backdrop is far from supportive , with signs that growth is slowing and increasing concerns that the government 's deficit reduction plan has stalled . ''
this chart shows how they expect borrowing over the next five years to be revised up , with no surplus in 2028-19 : .

george osborne 's original target of eliminating the structural deficit by the end of this parliament has long been dead in the water , of course , after the squeeze early in the parliament choked off growth .

the big worry for economists is that the obr may look at the worsening outlook for the economy , and the breakdown of the relationship between growth and the public finances , and conclude that the long-term prospects for the public finances are less healthy .
this all adds up to a fiscal straitjacket which gives limited room for manoeuvre .

but osborne can still create some wriggle-room by pledging a spending squeeze in the next parliament , without disclosing full details we can also expect to hear dread warning from the chancellor about the global economy deteriorating .
japan is back in recession , russia will soon follow , and the eurozone is barely growing and close to deflation .
growth figures overnight from australia were disappointing too .
gw

documents.title: autumn statement : the political view
text: members of the media outside number 11 downing street this morning , as chancellor george osborne prepares to make his autumn statement .
leal-olivas/pa today 's autumn statement is virtually the last big event in the political calendar before the general election .
there will be a budget in the spring , but that will be so close to the election that it will be little more than a party political broadcast ; it will affect very little before polling day .
autumn statements are , in practice , budgets too and today 's will involve decisions that will come into force before people vote .

the parameters of the 2015 general election campaign are already fairly clear - labour are fighting on the cost-of-living and the nhs , the tories have already played their tax cuts card and set out their immigration position - and , in truth , most of the political events between now and 7 may probably wo n't affect the outcome .
but the autumn statement is one of the few set piece moments that can shift the dial a bit .

here 's today 's guardian guide as to what to expect : autumn statement : from pork-barrel politics to sleight of hand , here 's what to expect i 'm andrew sparrow ( as ) and i 'll be blogging all day with my colleague graeme wearden ( gw ) .
we 'll be covering the statement in detail and then focusing on analysis and reaction , with a particular emphasis on small print alerts '' , highlighting the decisions hidden in the detail .
the statement is at 12.30pm .
